permissions.description:
Allows an app to access precise location. Alternatively, you might want ACCESS_COARSE_LOCATION.

Protection level: dangerous

Allows an app to access approximate location. Alternatively, you might want ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION.

Protection level: dangerous

Allows applications to open network sockets.

Protection level: normal

Allows applications to access information about networks.

Protection level: normal

Allows access to the vibrator.

Protection level: normal

Allows applications to access information about Wi-Fi networks.

Protection level: normal

vulnerabilityFindings.description:
By default (unless explicitly configured otherwise by the developer), Android allows a WebView to access content providers on the
device's file system. This is usually an unnecessary security risk.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation: Do not enable JavaScript file access in WebViews.
vulnerabilityFindings.title: App Enables Content Provider Access Through WebView

references.shortDescription: Do not allow WebView to access sensitive local resource through file scheme

referenceGroup.name: SEI CERT Oracle Coding Standard for Java
referenceGroup.description: The SEI CERT Oracle Coding Standard for Java

references.id: DRD02. Do not allow WebView to access sensitive local resource through file scheme

references.shortDescription: JavaScript is disabled in WebViews unless explicitly required.

references.shortDescription: WebViews are configured to allow only the minimum set of protocol handlers required (ideally, only https is supported). Potentially      dangerous handlers, such as file, tel and app-id, are disabled.

vulnerabilityFindings.description: The app configures a WebView such such that JavaScript code loaded from files can access any other resource (regardless of its type), effectively completely disabling the same origin policy for code executed from a JS file. This configuration even allows JavaScript code to access content providers and similar Android resources. Consequently, this vulnerability can lead to information disclosure from arbitrary resources. More information can be found here.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation: Do not enable JavaScript file access in WebViews.
vulnerabilityFindings.title: App Enables Arbitrary Resource Access For JavaScript Files

references.shortDescription: Do not allow WebView to access sensitive local resource through file scheme

vulnerabilityFindings.description:
The app is configured such that cookies for web requests can be loaded from local files using the 
file://
scheme. When sensitive information is stored in cookies that are accessible to other, potentially untrusted apps, the respective data can be leaked. Further, invalid data can potentially be injected via the cookie. Further, if the server requests a cookie from a local file, the app can leak sensitive information to a compromised or malicious server.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation:
Do not allow loading cookies from local files. Only exchange cookies with the appropriate remote
servers using TLS channels. Restrict the cookies to normal cookie storage in the browser, with
browser-based access control to link cookies to servers/domains (default behavior if no other cookie
policy is configured).
vulnerabilityFindings.title: Web Cookies Stored in Local Files

references.shortDescription: Use of Persistent Cookies Containing Sensitive Information

referenceGroup.name: CWE
referenceGroup.description: CWE™ is a community-developed list of common software security weaknesses. It serves as a common language, a measuring stick for software security tools, and as a baseline for weakness identification, mitigation, and prevention efforts.

referenceGroup.name: Android Developer Guide
referenceGroup.description: The Android developer guides, available at the Android Developer Homepage

vulnerabilityFindings.description:
The app uses the Chrome browser control to display web content. Through various HTML5 APIs, web sites can request
sensitive data, such as the user's current location, from the browser. If the browser is part of an app, the app
must decide whether to grant such requests or not. This app does not perform any checks, and instead always grants
all requested permissions. This is dangerous, because if an attacker manages to load untrusted JavaScript code inside
the browser control, he can again access to data outside of the browser and violate the user's privacy.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation: Always check permission requests from web content before granting them.
vulnerabilityFindings.title: Permission Request Always Accepted in Chrome Client

vulnerabilityFindings.description:
The app uses the Apache Cordova library to run content based on web technology (HTML and JavaScript).
In the Cordova configuration, the app allows this content to redirect to certain URLs. However, these URLs
are not specified explicitly, but through wildcards. Consequently, the set of servers with which the app
can exchange data is not restricted. Therefore, the app might send sensitive data to untrusted locations
or trust incomimg data from insecure sources. Even if such incoming data is not processed inside the app,
it might still be displayed to misguide users.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation: Explicitly specify remote server URLs in the configuration file. Do not use wildcards.
vulnerabilityFindings.title: Navigation to wildcards allowed in Cordova app

vulnerabilityFindings.description:
One or more permissions have been declared as used in the manifest file, but do not seem to be actually used by the
application.
In case a vulnerability exists that allows an attacker to inject code, the attacker can also use the permissions which
are otherwise unused by the app.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation: Do not declare permissions with uses-permission which the application does not need to run.
vulnerabilityFindings.title: Unused permissions

references.shortDescription: The app only requests the minimum set of permissions necessary.

references.shortDescription: Applications must only request Use Permissions or grant Permissions that are required for execution purposes.

additionalData.name: Method, might be called by another application

vulnerabilityFindings.description:
The concept of permissions enables the user to check what kind of actions applications can perform. This application
                 contains a vulnerability which third party applications can exploit to trigger actions or get data, for which they would
                 need to have a specific permission for.
Due to the vulnerability, they can trigger these actions on behalf of the vulnerable app without needing to have the
permission. This can be used to trick the user into thinking that the app does not require this permission.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation: If the component is only supposed to be used by other apps of the same developer, the app should define a new permission with the protection level signature. Other apps by the developer can use this permission. in order to do this, they need to be signed with the same key as the application containing the content provider. This ensures that no other application can access the content provider unless it has been signed by the same developer. If the component is supposed to be used by any other app, be sure to use checkCallingPermission to check whether the other app invoking the component has the appropriate permission.
vulnerabilityFindings.title: Other applications may trigger permission guarded actions without permissions

additionalData.name: Reason
additionalData.data: When running under Android 8.1 Oreo (API level 27), cleartext traffic is allowed by default

vulnerabilityFindings.description: Starting with Android 6.0 Marshmallow, Android has introduced a feature intended to disallow Apps to use cleartext traffic. Apps can opt out of this security feature through its security configuration file. However, this option should only be used if cleartext communication is absolutely required. Otherwise, apps should always communicate via secure protocols such as TLS. Note that WebView does not honor this flag.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation:
For security reasons, no cleartext traffic should be allowed in most cases. Exceptions to this rule are external sites that don't provide an encryption channel. These unsecure domains should be whitelisted explicitly while a secure channel should be expected for all other domains.
  • If cleartext traffic is generally not intended, set the android:usesCleartextTraffic attribute to false in the application element.
  • If cleartext traffic should be allowed for certain domains, a Network Security Configuration should be used. In order to use configuration file, specify in the Android manifest where the file is located. A network security configuration overrides the android:usesCleartextTraffic attribute.
vulnerabilityFindings.title: Cleartext traffic allowed
